'''Blind Arvella Gray''' (January 28, 1906 – September 7, 1980)<ref name="Dead"/> was an [[United States|American]] [[blues]], [[folk music|folk]] and [[Gospel music|gospel]] [[singing|singer]] and [[guitarist]].

His birth name was '''James Dixon''', and he was born in [[Somerville, Texas|Somerville]], [[Texas]], [[United States]].<ref name="Dead">[http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1980.html  Thedeadrockstarsclub.com] - accessed July 2010</ref> He spent the latter part of his life performing and [[busking]] folk, blues and gospel music at [[Chicago]]'s [[Maxwell Street]] flea market and at rapid-transit depots. In the '60s, he recorded two singles for his own Gray label including "Freedom Rider" backed with "Freedom Bus."

Gray's only [[album]], 1973's ''The Singing Drifter'' was reissued on the Conjuroo<ref>[http://www.conjuroo.com Conjuroo.com]</ref> [[record label]] in 2005. The re-issue [[record producer|producer]] was Cary Baker <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cary_Baker>, who wrote the liner notes for the original Birch Records [[Gramophone record|vinyl LP]].

Gray died in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] in September 1980, at the age of 74.<ref name="Dead"/>
